                    ### Question
                    A 9-year-old boy diagnosed as uncomplicated pulmonary tuberculosis. He is put on isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol at home after initial treatment given at hospital. Which is accurate statement for this scenario?

                    ### Options
                    opa. His 3-year-old sibling should receive INH prophylaxis
opb. A baseline test of auditory function test is essential before drug treatment is initiated
opc. Polyahralgia is a potential adverse effect of the drugs the boy is taking
opd. His mother, who takes care of him, does not need INH prophylaxis

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
In the case of a 9-year-old boy with uncomplicated pulmonary tuberculosis on isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol, the following points are relevant: 1) His 3-year-old sibling should receive INH prophylaxis as they are at risk of tuberculosis transmission from the boy. 2) A baseline auditory function test is not essential before initiating treatment with these drugs, as ethambutol primarily affects vision (optic neuritis) rather than hearing. 3) Polyarthralgia is not a commonly recognized adverse effect of isoniazid or rifampin; while some patients may experience joint pain, it is not a standard concern associated with these medications. 4) The mother does not need INH prophylaxis if she is not infected with tuberculosis, as prophylaxis is indicated only for those at risk of developing the disease. Therefore, the most accurate statement is that the sibling should receive INH prophylaxis.
